pullRequest.title: Add table function generate_subscripts
pullRequest.bodyText:
Convenience function that generates the set of valid subscripts for the
specified dimension of the given array. Zero rows are returned for arrays
that do not have the requested dimension, or for NULL arrays (but valid
subscripts are returned for NULL array elements).

nodes.diffHunk:
@@ -140,6 +140,54 @@ The return value always matches the ``start`` / ``stop`` types.
     +---------------+-----------------------------------+
     SELECT 3 rows in set (... sec)
 
+.. _table-functions-generate-subscripts:
+
+``generate_subscripts(array, dim, [reverse])``
+==============================================
+
+Generate the subscripts for the specified dimension ``dim`` of the given
+``array``. Zero rows are returned for arrays that do not have the requested
+dimension, or for NULL arrays (but valid subscripts are returned for NULL
+array elements).
+
+If ``reverse`` is ``true`` the subscripts will be returned in reverse order.
+
+::
+
+    cr> SELECT generate_subscripts([NULL,1,NULL,2], 1) AS s;

@@ -140,6 +140,54 @@ The return value always matches the ``start`` / ``stop`` types.
     +---------------+-----------------------------------+
     SELECT 3 rows in set (... sec)
 
+.. _table-functions-generate-subscripts:
+
+``generate_subscripts(array, dim, [reverse])``
+==============================================
+
+Generate the subscripts for the specified dimension ``dim`` of the given
+``array``. Zero rows are returned for arrays that do not have the requested
+dimension, or for NULL arrays (but valid subscripts are returned for NULL
+array elements).
+
+If ``reverse`` is ``true`` the subscripts will be returned in reverse order.
+
+::
+
+    cr> SELECT generate_subscripts([NULL,1,NULL,2], 1) AS s;
+    +---+
+    | s |
+    +---+
+    | 1 |
+    | 2 |
+    | 3 |
+    | 4 |
+    +---+
+    SELECT 4 rows in set (... sec)
+
+::
+
+    cr> SELECT generate_subscripts([NULL,1,NULL,2], 1, true) AS s;

nodes.bodyText: I am not sure that stream usage is justified here. It generates the boxed sequence, sorts it if needed, allocates additional unnecessary objects, etc. As an idea, can't we just have two int fields, e.g. from and to that we set depending on the reverse flag, also probably we need the sign, so we know whether we inc or dec or smth similar? Something like that will be definitely more efficient than the current stream API usage.

The same comment about the stream API usage. It is probably not that necessary to create a new stream object to iterate over a list and do some predicate checks. You can achieve that with the for-loop in a not less concise manner as well.
Same here, see the previous comments.
can we add tests that cover both scenarios?
maybe align this variable. not sure why we need another static field for it.
it is a bit confusing, array becomes nested?
not really related, but i am wondering whether assertions like these still make sense. isn't it already guarded by the func resolving/registration logic?

beforeCommit.message:
Add table function generate_subscripts

Convenience function that generates the set of valid subscripts for the
specified dimension of the given array. Zero rows are returned for arrays
that do not have the requested dimension, or for NULL arrays (but valid
subscripts are returned for NULL array elements).

nodes.bodyText:
Maybe add some prose to each example to highlight what the example illustrates.
Otherwise this looks like a random collection of examples and the reader has to decode the difference between them - which is difficult if you're just trying to learn about the function.

nodes.bodyText: Could move this check above the previous check, then the oi != null check could be removed as it becomes redundant.
I think the name doesn't really fit. It implies that it verifies some condition, but also has a return value without indicating what the value is about.
dim == null case needs to be handled as well. This causes a NullPointerException as it is.
This raises a NullPointerException if the reversed flag argument is null
What do you think about extracting parts of the evaluate of generate_series and re-using it here?
Is subscripts the right field-name?

afterCommit.message:
Change the name of the column, because see below:

postgres=# select * from generate_subscripts('{1}'::int[], 1);
 generate_subscripts
---------------------
                   1
(1 row)

beforeCommit.message:
Change the name of the column, because see below:

postgres=# select * from generate_subscripts('{1}'::int[], 1);
 generate_subscripts
---------------------
                   1
(1 row)

afterCommit.message: Two functions that belong to the pg_catalog

nodes.diffHunk:
@@ -140,6 +140,94 @@ The return value always matches the ``start`` / ``stop`` types.
     +---------------+-----------------------------------+
     SELECT 3 rows in set (... sec)
 
+.. _table-functions-generate-subscripts:
+
+``pg_catalog.generate_subscripts(array, dim, [reverse])``
+=========================================================
+
+Generate the subscripts for the specified dimension ``dim`` of the given
+``array``. Zero rows are returned for arrays that do not have the requested
+dimension, or for NULL arrays (but valid subscripts are returned for NULL
+array elements).
+
+If ``reverse`` is ``true`` the subscripts will be returned in reverse order.
+
+This example takes a one dimensional array of four elements, where elements
+at positions 1 and 3 are NULL:
+
+::
+
+    cr> SELECT generate_subscripts([NULL, 1, NULL, 2], 1) AS s;
+    +---+
+    | s |
+    +---+
+    | 1 |
+    | 2 |
+    | 3 |
+    | 4 |
+    +---+
+    SELECT 4 rows in set (... sec)
+
+This example returns the reversed list of subscripts for the same array:
+
+::
+
+    cr> SELECT generate_subscripts([NULL, 1, NULL, 2], 1, true) AS s;
+    +---+
+    | s |
+    +---+
+    | 4 |
+    | 3 |
+    | 2 |
+    | 1 |
+    +---+
+    SELECT 4 rows in set (... sec)
+
+The following examples work on an array of three dimensions. Each of the elements
+within a given level must be either NULL, or an array of the same size as the other
+arrays within the same level.

nodes.bodyText:
Suggested change
        
          
    

        
      
    
    
      
          
            
                cr> select generate_subscripts([[[1],[2]], [[3],[4]], [[4],[5]]], 3) as s;
          
          
            
                +---+
          
          
            
                | s |
          
          
            
                +---+
          
          
            
                | 1 |
          
          
            
                +---+
          
          
            
                SELECT 1 row in set (... sec)
          
          
            
            
          
          
            
            ::
          
          
            
            
          
          
            
                cr> select generate_subscripts([ [[1], null], [[3], [null]], [null, null]], 3) as s;
          
          
            
                +---+
          
          
            
                | s |
          
          
            
                +---+
          
          
            
                | 1 |
          
          
            
                +---+
          
          
            
                SELECT 1 row in set (... sec)
          
          
            
            
          
          
            
            ::
          
          
            
            
          
          
            
                cr> select generate_subscripts([ [[1], null], [[3], [null]], [null, null]], 2) as s;
          
          
            
                +---+
          
          
            
                | s |
          
          
            
                +---+
          
          
            
                | 1 |
          
          
            
                | 2 |
          
          
            
                +---+
          
          
            
                SELECT 2 rows in set (... sec)
          
      
    
    
  

I think one example of the multi-dimensional case is enough. We don't need to cover all kind of edge cases or so for documentation purposes.

+.. _table-functions-generate-subscripts:
+
+``pg_catalog.generate_subscripts(array, dim, [reverse])``
+=========================================================
+
+Generate the subscripts for the specified dimension ``dim`` of the given
+``array``. Zero rows are returned for arrays that do not have the requested
+dimension, or for NULL arrays (but valid subscripts are returned for NULL
+array elements).
+
+If ``reverse`` is ``true`` the subscripts will be returned in reverse order.
+
+This example takes a one dimensional array of four elements, where elements
+at positions 1 and 3 are NULL:
+
+::
+
+    cr> SELECT generate_subscripts([NULL, 1, NULL, 2], 1) AS s;
+    +---+
+    | s |
+    +---+
+    | 1 |
+    | 2 |
+    | 3 |
+    | 4 |
+    +---+
+    SELECT 4 rows in set (... sec)
+
+This example returns the reversed list of subscripts for the same array:
+
+::
+
+    cr> SELECT generate_subscripts([NULL, 1, NULL, 2], 1, true) AS s;
+    +---+
+    | s |
+    +---+
+    | 4 |
+    | 3 |
+    | 2 |
+    | 1 |
+    +---+
+    SELECT 4 rows in set (... sec)
+
+The following examples work on an array of three dimensions. Each of the elements
+within a given level must be either NULL, or an array of the same size as the other
+arrays within the same level.
+
+::
+
+    cr> select generate_subscripts([[[1],[2]], [[3],[4]], [[4],[5]]], 2) as s;
+    +---+
+    | s |
+    +---+
+    | 1 |
+    | 2 |
+    +---+
+    SELECT 2 rows in set (... sec)
+
+::
+
+    cr> select generate_subscripts([[[1],[2]], [[3],[4]], [[4],[5]]], 3) as s;
+    +---+
+    | s |
+    +---+
+    | 1 |
+    +---+
+    SELECT 1 row in set (... sec)
+
+::
+
+    cr> select generate_subscripts([ [[1], null], [[3], [null]], [null, null]], 3) as s;
+    +---+
+    | s |
+    +---+
+    | 1 |
+    +---+
+    SELECT 1 row in set (... sec)
+

+

nodes.bodyText: Why the change to Bucket? This can still be an Iterable, the additional size info of Bucket is not required or used.

I think the U extends Number constraint is unecessary, no?
Also not sure about the name. I think it emphases the SingleColumn part too much. How about just RangeIterator, SeriesGenerator, or GenerateSeriesIterator ?
Also, could this an Iterable? Would make it a bit more powerful

commit.message:
Add table function generate_subscripts

Convenience function that generates the set of valid subscripts for the
specified dimension of the given array. Zero rows are returned for arrays
that do not have the requested dimension, or for NULL arrays (but valid
subscripts are returned for NULL array elements).

specified dimension of the given array. Zero rows are returned for arrays
that do not have the requested dimension, or for NULL arrays (but valid
subscripts are returned for NULL array elements).
